Start by naming them "resultSet" and "statement", since that's what they are.

Next, consider using gsbase (http://gsbase.sourceforge.net) which contains "smart" wrappers that do the necessary cleanup. Then you don't have to worry about it yourself. Don't reinvent the wheel.

Next, find a Mock implementation of JDBC that includes setting expectations on the 'close' method. Start with either a web search or at http://www.mockobjects.com. Good luck.

Finally, if you want to do something by hand yourself, substitute a dynamic proxy to ResultSet and Statement in your tests, then verify that the proxy received "close".

Good luck.

So said wxcodemaster on 3/14/2003 --------------------
i have a method within factory class A that does
rs.close()    (ResultSet)
stmt.close()   (PreparedStatement)

in my junit test class i want to check
that after execution of this method
rs and stmt are really closed.

is there an easy way to do this? (rs and stmt are both member 
variables of class A)

thank you!

t.
